alternateName: Analyzing job market and skills required for data professionals

distribution.name: archive.zip
distribution.description: Archive containing all the contents of the Data Science Job Postings & Skills (2024) dataset

distribution.name: job_postings.csv
distribution.description: A raw dump of the database used to scrape Linkedin. Contains information such as job titles, company names, locations, search parameters, and more.

distribution.name: job_skills.csv
distribution.description: Contains all the skills mentioned in the job description

field.name: job_link
field.description: Direct link to the job posting on LinkedIn. (type: str)

field.name: last_processed_time
field.description: Timestamp indicating the last time the job posting was processed. (type: datetime)

field.name: last_status
field.description: The last status of the job posting (e.g., processed, pending). (type: str)

field.name: got_summary
field.description: Indicates whether the job summary was successfully extracted or not. (type: bool)

field.name: got_ner
field.description: Indicates whether named entities were successfully extracted from the job posting. (type: bool)

field.name: is_being_worked
field.description: Shows if the job posting is currently being worked on. (type: bool)

field.name: job_title
field.description: Title of the job posting. (type: str)

field.name: company
field.description: Name of the company offering the job. (type: str)

field.name: job_location
field.description: Location of the job (e.g., city, state, country). (type: str)

field.name: first_seen
field.description: Timestamp indicating when the job posting was first observed. (type: date)

field.name: search_city
field.description: City used as a search parameter when collecting the data. (type: str)

field.name: search_country
field.description: Country used as a search parameter when collecting the data. (type: str)

field.name: search_position
field.description: Position or job title used as a search parameter when collecting the data. (type: str)

field.name: job_level
field.description: Level of the job (e.g., entry-level, senior, management). (type: str)

field.name: job_type
field.description: Type of job (e.g., full-time, part-time, contract). (type: str)

recordSet.name: job_postings.csv
recordSet.description: A raw dump of the database used to scrape Linkedin. Contains information such as job titles, company names, locations, search parameters, and more.

field.name: job_skills
field.description: Skills extracted via AI from the job description. Do split(, ) to convert to a list (type: str)

recordSet.name: job_skills.csv
recordSet.description: Contains all the skills mentioned in the job description

keywords: subject > science and technology > computer science
subject > people and society > jobs and career
subject > people and society > jobs and career > employment
subject > science and technology > internet > online communities > social networks
name: Data Science Job Postings & Skills (2024)
description: LinkedIn is a popular professional networking platform with millions of job postings across various industries. This dataset provides a raw dump of data science-related job postings collected from LinkedIn. It includes information about job titles, companies, locations, search parameters, and other relevant details. The main objective of this dataset is not only to provide insights into the data science job market and the skills required by professionals in this field but also to offer users an opportunity to practice their data cleaning skills. By working with this dataset, users can gain hands-on experience in cleaning and preprocessing raw data, a critical skill for aspiring data scientists. > If you find this dataset useful or interesting, please upvote it! 😊💝 ## Interesting Task Ideas: 1. Practice data cleaning techniques 2. Analyze the most in-demand job titles for data science professionals. 3. Identify the top companies hiring for data science positions. 4. Determine the most common job locations for data science roles. 5. Explore the relationship between job level and required skills. 6. Explore the prevalence of certain skills or technologies within different industries. 7. Use natural language processing techniques to extract key information from job titles or summaries. --- Photo by Luke Chesser on Unsplash
